an5.31:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an5.31:1.2: Then Princess Sumanā, escorted by five hundred chariots and five hundred royal maidens, went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
an5.31:2.1: “Sir, suppose there were two disciples equal in faith, ethics, and wisdom.
an5.31:2.2: One is a giver, one is not.
an5.31:2.3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
an5.31:2.4: When they have become gods, would there be any distinction or difference between them?”
an5.31:3.1: “There would be, Sumanā,” said the Buddha.
an5.31:3.2: “As a god, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in five respects:
an5.31:3.3: divine lifespan, beauty, happiness, fame, and sovereignty.
an5.31:3.4: As a god, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in these five respects.”
an5.31:4.1: “But sir, if they pass away from there and come back to this state of existence as human beings, would there still be any distinction or difference between them?”
an5.31:4.2: “There would be, Sumanā,” said the Buddha.
an5.31:4.3: “As a human being, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in five respects:
an5.31:4.4: human lifespan, beauty, happiness, fame, and sovereignty.
an5.31:4.5: As a human being, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in these five respects.”
an5.31:5.1: “But sir, if they both go forth from the lay life to homelessness, would there still be any distinction or difference between them?”
an5.31:5.2: “There would be, Sumanā,” said the Buddha.
an5.31:5.3: “As a renunciate, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in five respects.
an5.31:5.4: They’d usually use only what they’ve been invited to accept—robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—rarely using them without invitation.
an5.31:5.5: When living with other spiritual practitioners, they usually treat them agreeably by way of body, speech, and mind, rarely disagreeably.
an5.31:5.6: As a renunciate, the one who was a giver would surpass the other in these five respects.”
an5.31:6.1: “But sir, if they both attain perfection, as perfected ones would there still be any distinction or difference between them?”
an5.31:6.2: “In that case, I say there is no difference between the freedom of one and the freedom of the other.”
an5.31:7.2: Just this much is quite enough to justify giving gifts and making merit.
an5.31:7.3: For merit is helpful for those who have become gods, human beings, and renunciates.”
an5.31:7.5: It’s quite enough to justify giving gifts and making merit.
an5.31:7.6: For merit is helpful for those who have become gods, human beings, and renunciates.”
an5.31:8.1: That is what the Buddha said.
an5.31:8.2: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
an5.31:9.2: journeying across the dimension of space;
an5.31:11.2: its hundred peaks wreathed in lightning,
an5.31:11.3: pours down over the rich earth,
an5.31:12.1: Even so, an astute person accomplished in vision,
an5.31:12.2: a disciple of the fully awakened Buddha,
an5.31:13.4: they depart to rejoice in heaven.”
